utterances: And Eddie bit them again and again and again.
And I can't even be mad at Eddie.
And let me tell you why.
Black Enterprise's - was - the head guy, Earl Graves claims that he wants to uplift black people.
Then why didn't he use all of the money that they paid Eddie Griffin to bring on someone like Bridget Gray or Jill Scott?
And I understand you just retired yesterday.
Congratulations.
There were so many artists that they could have had on to perform at their event.
But they elected to select Eddie Griffin, and I think anyone who's looked at Griffin's body of work might conclude that it might not meet Earl Graves' standards.
And then, for the - then - I don't know if you all saw Roland Martin's blog where Butch, who is Earl Graves' son, is saying, you know, Eddie Griffin promised to do a clean show.
He put it in his contract.
(Unintelligible) video.
You don't think he's not capable to doing a clean show.
Yeah.
That's why I'm like, wait a minute.
If you have to get a comedian to put in the contract, I will do a clean show, then maybe that's not the comedian you need to have at your poo-poo CHIDEYA:-chi golfing event.
So I say wonderful for Eddie.
Black Enterprise got exactly what they deserved.
And Earl Graves and Butch Graves, stop funding foolishness and you won't end up with a situation like this.
Well, Michael, I just want to add to whatever else you were going to say.
The question - the N-word had its funeral by the NAACP, what's the state of play overall?
Well, I think it's a generational state of playing.

The people who attended the Black Enterprise conference, by the way, you know, you're talking about 40-something, 50-something-year-old business folks who tend to be resistant to the kind of comedy that Eddie Griffin provides.
So I think it depends - in all - in many cases, on where you stand, generationally, culturally and what-not, I'd like subversive comedy, although I think Eddie Griffin is overrated as a comedian.
(Soundbite of laughter)
But, you know, the person who booked this show needs to answer questions.
He should be fired.
He should be fired.
Of all the people in the world to book, why would you book Eddie Griffin?
You know what he does.

Now, conversely, I give the people credit for pulling him off the stage, although he shouldn't have been there in the first place because if we're not going to be pulling people off the stage for that kind of stuff, then why can we get upset - why do we get upset when all the people do?
Want to do a quick pop on the Jena Six case.
The African-American kids who were basically jumped - they jumped a white student after a racial incident with a noose.
Now, there has been so much activism around this.
David, do you think that it is critical, good, bad that blogs are basically pushing a social movement around this?
Around this case, I have my problems with it.
I wish I'm - yeah, I'm with Jena.
I wish more people talking about Dunbar Village, you know?
Mm-hmm.

There are things more horrific and more indicative of the crisis of the culture of violence in black America that we need to address and get behind than a case where, you know - it's a six on one, jumping, stomping, knocking a guy unconscious.
You know, why are they mobilizing, you know?
And if it's all about the nooses, I mean, that happened months before.
And again, what - we get hung up on imagery or something.
Michael.

Well, you know, I wonder if the blogosphere or as I like to call them the blogorazzi, are really focused on this to - you know, I'm not necessarily sure that we're getting a whole lot of play on this.
I mean, there are selected sites out there that are doing things but this isn't getting nearly the play that the Duke lacrosse scandal did.
And I agree there are so many cases out there that we need to be focused on.
And hopefully, this will be the start of a wider view of what's going on in these types of cases, particularly in the South.
You know, for city black folks, this is an Albany(ph) of experiences on what goes on in the other parts of the South or around the country generally.
All right.
Gina, real quick.

I just think that this is demonstrating the fact that the - about the emerging power of the black blogosphere and also viral e-mails and the black syndicated radio shows because we have our own kind of Negro spiritual network where we're communicating with each other, kind of below the radar.
But black people are learning about this story in a nontraditional way.
I agree.
Well, lady and gentlemen, thank you.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Thank you.
We've been talking with David Mills of the blog, Undercover Black Man.
He was with me here in our NPR West Studios.
Michael Fauntroy is an assistant professor of public policy at George Mason University.
He blogs at michaelfauntroy.com and spoke with us from NPR's Washington, D.C.
headquarters.
And from member station KUT in Austin, Texas, Gina McCauley.
Her blog is called What About Our Daughters.
And you can find links to their blogs and ours at nprnewsandnotes.org.
The conversation doesn't stop here either.
Our online series, Speak Your Mind, gives you a chance to sound off on the issues you care about.
To find out how, go to our blog, nprnewsandviews.org, and click on Speak Your Mind.
We wanted to get a sense of the broad effects of the federal government shutdown, so we've gathered tape from across the country.
They said you can't get inside because of this situation.
I was, like, no, what am I going to do?
That's Jennifer Wilson (ph), a fourth-grade teacher from Port St. Lucie, Fla.
She drove all the way to the Martin Luther King Jr. National Historic Site in Atlanta this week only to find it closed.
So when I got here, I wanted to cry.
And if you think about standing in there or just being in there for 22 and a half hours a day, it just, you would just walk yourself in circles.
But of course, it's not just tourists being affected by the shutdown.
Hundreds of thousands of federal workers are in limbo, including Sharon Stiteler, a park ranger for the Mississippi National River and Recreation Area.
Like the other federal workers we talked to, she speaks for herself, not her employer.
Whether or not I go back to work is someone else's decision.
She's been through four government shutdowns.
Sometimes at 2:00 a.m., I might have a bit of a panic attack that, you know, I'm not a useful contributor to my household.
And, my goodness, maybe I should not have bought, you know, the more expensive lettuce today.
Who knows how much longer the shutdown's going to last?
You know, I'm not over here kicking it on the beach, drinking pina coladas.
That's Ernie Johnson.
He's a geologist with the Bureau of Land Management.
He says that for many workers who don't have a backup fund, the shutdown means stressing about bills and finding ways to make ends meet.
He's considering moving out of his home and onto a friend's couch.
I'm just looking at the reality that, you know, I may not be able to pay rent.
He's not alone.
Julie Burr, an administrative assistant in the Department of Transportation, is a single mom.
She's keeping busy at a second job she picked up to see her family through the shutdown.
That's only about 25 percent of my pay that I make at my federal job, so it's not going to pay all of my bills, obviously.
She's a contractor, so even if other federal workers are granted back pay after the shutdown, she is unlikely to see any of that money.
I guess the drastic thing would be to start taking back Christmas gifts or, you know, maybe selling things.
I don't know.
I hope it doesn't come to that.
That's a worst-case scenario.
But since they don't know how long they'll be without work, federal workers like Ernie Johnson are planning for the worst.
So, you know, I have my contingency plans.
And, right now, everything is budgeted, you know, kind of through the end of the month.
But now it's just a matter of a wait game.
(SOUNDBITE OF PALOV'S ""LOKUMS AND MATCHES"")
The Ukrainian government has declared martial law and put its armed forces on alert.
This comes after yesterday's clash between Ukrainian and Russian naval ships.
And at the U.N., European members of the Security Council demanded that Russia allow free navigation and release the captured Ukrainian vessels and their sailors.
NPR's Lucian Kim has the latest from Moscow.
There's little debate about what happened Sunday when three Ukrainian naval vessels attempted to pass through a narrow bottleneck separating the Crimean Peninsula and the Russian mainland.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
